g.title:
<
6. Bg5
Threats to exchange the bishop for the
knight so black's d pawn can be captured. 6. ..
dxc4 White has two options: either take the c4
pawn or push the d pawn.
>
g.text: Threats to exchange the bishop for the
knight so black's d pawn can be captured.
White has two options: either take the c4
pawn or push the d pawn.

g.title:
<
7. d5
TODO
Instead of taking c4 pawn white aggressively
pushes the d pawn. Black can either 7. ..
Ne5 or 7. .. Na5 both leading to very sharp
lines. After 8. Qd4 both 8. .. Nd3+ and 8. .. h6
are playable options. 8. .. Ng6 is considered
an inaccuracy or even a mistake.
>
g.text: Instead of taking c4 pawn white aggressively
pushes the d pawn. Black can either
or 7. .. Na5 both leading to very sharp
are playable options. 8. .. Ng6 is considered
an inaccuracy or even a mistake.

g.title:
<
6. Bg5
Threats to exchange the bishop for the
knight so black's d pawn can be captured. 6. ..
dxc4 White has two options: either take the c4
pawn or push the d pawn.
>-><
7. d5
TODO
Instead of taking c4 pawn white aggressively
pushes the d pawn. Black can either 7. ..
Ne5 or 7. .. Na5 both leading to very sharp
lines. After 8. Qd4 both 8. .. Nd3+ and 8. .. h6
are playable options. 8. .. Ng6 is considered
an inaccuracy or even a mistake.
>

<
7. Bxc4
 7. Bxc4 h6 Black playing against a white
IQP. 7. .. h6 forces the white bishop to
choose diagonal, if bishop exchanges for the
knight black already equalised.
>
g.text: IQP. 7. .. h6 forces the white bishop to
choose diagonal, if bishop exchanges for the

g.title:
<
6. Bg5
Threats to exchange the bishop for the
knight so black's d pawn can be captured. 6. ..
dxc4 White has two options: either take the c4
pawn or push the d pawn.
>-><
7. Bxc4
 7. Bxc4 h6 Black playing against a white
IQP. 7. .. h6 forces the white bishop to
choose diagonal, if bishop exchanges for the
knight black already equalised.
>

<
8. Bh4
 8. .. Qxd4 both white bishops are under
attack so 9. Qxd4 Nxd4 10. 0-0-0 white gave a
pawn for development advantage. Black can 10.
.. e5 leading to a very sharp game,
recommended move 10. .. g5 if 11. Bg3 Ne6 protecting c7
against white knight fork attempts. So white
usually plays 11. Rxd4 gxh4 12. Nb5 e5 
protecting against mate with Nc7+. 13. Nc7+ Ke7 14.
Rxh4 Rb8 Material is equal, black has bishop
pair and slightly misplaced king.
>
g.text: pawn for development advantage. Black can 10.
.. e5 leading to a very sharp game,
against white knight fork attempts. So white
Material is equal, black has bishop

g.title:
<
7. Bxc4
 7. Bxc4 h6 Black playing against a white
IQP. 7. .. h6 forces the white bishop to
choose diagonal, if bishop exchanges for the
knight black already equalised.
>-><
8. Bh4
 8. .. Qxd4 both white bishops are under
attack so 9. Qxd4 Nxd4 10. 0-0-0 white gave a
pawn for development advantage. Black can 10.
.. e5 leading to a very sharp game,
recommended move 10. .. g5 if 11. Bg3 Ne6 protecting c7
against white knight fork attempts. So white
usually plays 11. Rxd4 gxh4 12. Nb5 e5 
protecting against mate with Nc7+. 13. Nc7+ Ke7 14.
Rxh4 Rb8 Material is equal, black has bishop
pair and slightly misplaced king.
>

<
8. Be3
TODO
 8. .. e6 developing to Bf5 is problematic
because of Qb3 9. Nf3 Bd6 10. 0-0 0-0 11. Re1
b6 with ideas of eventual Bb7 and Nb4-Nd5
blockading white's IQP. Todo: b5 seems to be
pretty weak, how to defend against white
dislocating the Bd6?
>
g.text: with ideas of eventual Bb7 and Nb4-Nd5
blockading white's IQP. Todo: b5 seems to be
pretty weak, how to defend against white

g.title:
<
7. Bxc4
 7. Bxc4 h6 Black playing against a white
IQP. 7. .. h6 forces the white bishop to
choose diagonal, if bishop exchanges for the
knight black already equalised.
>-><
8. Be3
TODO
 8. .. e6 developing to Bf5 is problematic
because of Qb3 9. Nf3 Bd6 10. 0-0 0-0 11. Re1
b6 with ideas of eventual Bb7 and Nb4-Nd5
blockading white's IQP. Todo: b5 seems to be
pretty weak, how to defend against white
dislocating the Bd6?
>

<
The Panov-Botvinnik Attack
 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. c4 
usually continues with 4. .. Nf6 5. Nc3 Nc6 
Instead of 5. .. Nc6 other options are 5. ..
e6 (somewhat passive) and 5. .. g6
(tactically sound)
>
g.text: 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. c4
Instead of 5. .. Nc6 other options are 5. ..

g.title:
<
The Panov-Botvinnik Attack
 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. c4 
usually continues with 4. .. Nf6 5. Nc3 Nc6 
Instead of 5. .. Nc6 other options are 5. ..
e6 (somewhat passive) and 5. .. g6
(tactically sound)
>-><
6. Bg5
Threats to exchange the bishop for the
knight so black's d pawn can be captured. 6. ..
dxc4 White has two options: either take the c4
pawn or push the d pawn.
>

<
6. Nf3
mainLine
 6. .. Bg4 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Qb3 white
attacking black's weak points and ignores the
attempt to damage her king side pawn
structure. If white does not play actively
black can play e6 and consolidate his
position with the bishop outside the pawn
chain and white's IQP. 8.
.. Bxf3 9. gxf3 If white captures 9. Qxb7
instead of recapturing her queen is lost
after 9. .. Ndb4. 9. .. e6 10. Qxb7 Nxd4 11. Bb5+
Nxb5 12. Qc6+ (black king has to move) 12. ..
Ke7 13. Qxb5 Qd7 14. Nxd5 Qxd5 15. Qxd5 exd5 
equal position with some complications.
>
g.text: attacking black's weak points and ignores the
attempt to damage her king side pawn
structure. If white does not play actively
black can play e6 and consolidate his
position with the bishop outside the pawn
instead of recapturing her queen is lost
Ke7 13. Qxb5 Qd7 14. Nxd5 Qxd5 15. Qxd5 exd5

g.title:
<
The Panov-Botvinnik Attack
 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. c4 
usually continues with 4. .. Nf6 5. Nc3 Nc6 
Instead of 5. .. Nc6 other options are 5. ..
e6 (somewhat passive) and 5. .. g6
(tactically sound)
>-><
6. Nf3
mainLine
 6. .. Bg4 7. cxd5 Nxd5 8. Qb3 white
attacking black's weak points and ignores the
attempt to damage her king side pawn
structure. If white does not play actively
black can play e6 and consolidate his
position with the bishop outside the pawn
chain and white's IQP. 8.
.. Bxf3 9. gxf3 If white captures 9. Qxb7
instead of recapturing her queen is lost
after 9. .. Ndb4. 9. .. e6 10. Qxb7 Nxd4 11. Bb5+
Nxb5 12. Qc6+ (black king has to move) 12. ..
Ke7 13. Qxb5 Qd7 14. Nxd5 Qxd5 15. Qxd5 exd5 
equal position with some complications.
>
